channel.title: Enum or txt file
channel.description: What would be better to load data from especially if your going to have lots of data.

item.title: Enum or txt file
item.dc:creator: @Cres Cres
item.description:
@Cres wrote:

Because you can reload data without having to compile or close your program when using an external source.
Because the length of your program is greatly reduced since your data won’t be an actual part of your program.
Can’t think of others, those are the 2 main reasons though (as to why you should use external sources).

Read full topic

item.title: Enum or txt file
item.dc:creator: @Wintercanon Wintercanon
item.description:
@Wintercanon wrote:

Using an enum is hardcoding your definitions. You don’t want to need to recompile your source code to change a definition; which is why hardcoding is frowned upon. Also consider the extra number of lines your compiler will need to read, parse and interpret if you have a lot of data.

Read full topic

item.title: Enum or txt file
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:10, topic:534006”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=652801.msg4374107#msg4374107 date=1381569743]

[quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=652801.msg4374103#msg4374103 date=1381566104]

[quote author=Strucker link=topic=652801.msg4374048#msg4374048 date=1381555678]

[quote author=Clawz fury link=topic=652801.msg4373960#msg4373960 date=1381535992]
if you have a lot of data it would be best to load from an external source.
[/quote]y
[/quote]so that you don’t use up all of your memory??
[/quote]not sure if trolling

once you load the data from an external source into java it will still use up the memory

@OP - It really depends what the data is, in most cases if it’s a lot of data you want an external source (JSON or flat file with your own format)
[/quote]WHY DOES EVERYONE KEEP SAYING IM TROLLING FFS, IM NOT EVEN WRONG
there are 99999 ways that loading from files will save you memory. you can just read the file when you need it, do what you want to do with it, then release it from memory. you can also read files sequentially so that you can process the data without putting the entire thing in memory. and databases have a huge number of benefits that i can’t even be bothered to list.[/quote]Compared to an enum, which is essentially creating instances of a class with predefined values, loading it from a file (assuming you would be creating an instance of a class with that data loaded, which is the only thing that makes sense if you had the option of using an enum) would not save you any memory.

Read full topic

if you have a lot of data it would be best to load from an external source.
[/quote]y
[/quote]so that you don’t use up all of your memory??
[/quote]not sure if trolling

once you load the data from an external source into java it will still use up the memory

@OP - It really depends what the data is, in most cases if it’s a lot of data you want an external source (JSON or flat file with your own format)[/quote]WHY DOES EVERYONE KEEP SAYING IM TROLLING FFS, IM NOT EVEN WRONG
there are 99999 ways that loading from files will save you memory. you can just read the file when you need it, do what you want to do with it, then release it from memory. you can also read files sequentially so that you can process the data without putting the entire thing in memory. and databases have a huge number of benefits that i can’t even be bothered to list.

item.title: Enum or txt file
item.dc:creator: @King_JC King JC
item.description:
@King_JC wrote:

I personally use text files to store global variables (such as the date and time I have running in my server). The only way to remember things like that, if the server is shut down, is to save externally. Like a player save.

Read full topic
